results.title: This way up
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Mike Jackson
results.brief_description:
James Burke goes to the top of the Blackpool Tower and turns upside down to discover how the ears talk to the eyes and how we know which way is down. Looks at the sense of balance and other ways we perceive which way is up. The use of vision and retinal cells to detect movement and distance is studied in detail.
Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: This vital earth
results.creator_credit: The Conservation Foundation, New York Zoological Society and George E. Brewer Jnr
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Living Earth”
The relation of life to its environment is shown through the balance of plants and animals. The film shows that plant and animal inter-relationships are essential for the survival of both.

results.title: This time, next time
results.creator_credit: Honky Tonk Angel Productions and Robin de Crespigny
results.brief_description: This program reveals the alarming facts about the condition of Alcohol Related Brain Damage (ARBD) showing how it takes a comparatively small quantity of alcohol and a short amount of time to cause significant and irreparable damage to the brain. “This Time, Next Time” combines both documentary and dramatic filmmaking techniques and cleverly intercuts actual medical experts, brain damaged patients and their families, with dramatic sequences. Cast includes Nicholas Gledhill, Patrick Dickson, Michele Fawdon, Kate Fitzpatrick, Kerry Mack, Terence Donovan.

results.title: This sporting life
results.creator_credit: Independent Artists (GB), Karel Reisz and Lindsay Anderson
results.brief_description: Richard Harris gives a superb performance as Yorkshire coal miner Frank Machin, who dreams of achieving public acclaim by making a name for himself on the City Rugby team. He performs with tenacity and aggressiveness and earns a place on the team as well as 1000 pounds. His desire of being well liked extends to his personal life as he seeks the approval and affections of his widowed landlady Mrs Hammond (Rachel Roberts). After initial resistance the two become lovers and it is at this physical level that their relationship remains. When Frank’s friend marries, Mrs Hammond is racked with bitterness about her relationship and Frank responds in the only way he knows how, with violence. As tragedy strikes, Frank is left only with his sporting life. Also starring Colin Blakely, Alan Badel and William Hartnell and adapted by David Storey from his own novel.
